title: How to teach elementary students - Quora

response.answer_text: I have, at one time, taught all levels from nursery school through college. There are unique differences in approach and methodology. Nursery, everything must be short termed and playful. Now. your question was about primary. Primary students are all about getting noticed. They are totally eager to please you. You are the parent figure. You must heap a great deal of praise on them!! They eat that up!! They want to be noticed and recognized. Positive reinforcement is the key at primary grades. “Who is going to be good for me today?” “Look at Susie, sitting straight and paying attention. “ “See how nicely Bobby is walking in the hallway?” There is a guide entitled “100 Ways To Say Good Job.” I suggest you find that online and use every one of those phrases. Use little rewards. Stickers, play money, etc. Some teachers have “teacher money” for good behavior. Earn so much and you get a reward from the “treasure Box.” Some schools even have “school money” and a school store. Circulate around the room. look students in the eye. Kneel or sit on their level. Have stations for 30 minutes or so. Above all, praise, praise, praise!! At a high school level, the dynamic is almost reversed. The kids want to fit in with their unit. Most do not want to be noticed. They would rather fit in with peers than please you. The best thing you can do is NOT call them out. Let them blend in and assimilate as part of the “pack.” The little kids strive to be “teacher’s helper/pet.” The high school kids avoid it like the plagued!! With high school kids, you appeal to “maturity” and cooperation, not control. “I’d like to thank you allowing me to teach you today and I’d like to thank you, in advance for your cooperation.” OR “You know why I’m here. I have a job to do. You have a job to do. Let’s do our jobs.” “You know how to act by now.” In high school, don’t use the term “rules”. Use “social contract.” Don’t mandate. Discuss. Get input, but you make final decisions. So, primary, circulate, notice, praise, reward!! (Notice I did not mention middle school, grades 7–8. They are the most difficult to teach.)

Play way method is the best method. Use daily life examples that would interest them most to explain the concept. E. g. Some cartoon character of their interest or say their favourite food like pizza for explaining fraction etc. Activity based learning is permanent. At the same time, as a teacher keep in mind that activities should be small and precise. Otherwise completing syllabus can be a headache. E.g. for factors affecting evaporation just ask for 3 handkerchiefs. Let them dry one spread completely the other kept folded third kept in front of a fan level and then explain it depends on surface area, wind speed etc. See to it that the basic concepts of the topic, may be grammar, basic maths concepts… are made clear. Usually if the children like the way you teach a particular subject, they start loving that subject forever. And vice versa… D on't be very strict but at the same time let them know that no nonsense is tolerated. Let discipline and live go hand in hand and you will definitely can win their hearts…. Fir whole of your life… The love that you get from primary children, you might not get it from higher class students…

In the primary grades, the students are building a base in learning, hence, all new concepts and topics should be approached with lots of varied activities and innovative techniques that makes learning fun and the impact of the learning permanent. The primary classes are responsible for creative a positive outlook towards learning upon students therefore, the lessons need to be interactive and immersive at all times.

If you are teaching the primary school students then these are the skills that a tutor should have. These are the basic skills that a teacher should have: A good teacher needs patience in order to find a way to work with his students and earn their respect.Good teachers know how to adapt their lesson plans to their students so that all the kids learn optimally.You have a better communication skills.As a teacher, you should have the confidence to teach the students.You should always be prepared to face conflicts.

Although according to methodology and pedagogy patience is the must quality but you need to have qualities like: Subject knowledgeGood behavioual traits(as they follow their teachers blindly at this age)Classroom managment strategies ( earlier it was considered as indiscipline but they can't sit as objects…so you have to be ready for tackling this issue)

you want to know the right method… ask the students…discover their learning styles, learning needs, interests…then re-design each engagement… concept: contextualise the content, methods and resources… (most of the teachers are repeating is my observation)
There is no one best way to teach a group of students. Teachers should use a myriad of methods to ensure that they hit all learning styles that are in the classroom.

Reading, writing, math, world history, geography, biology, archeology, ancient myths, world literature, art, music, evolution, astronomy, sciences (physics, chemistry, atomic structure), government functions, economics. That gets us through the 8th grade. 9 through 12 should focus on college prep or a vocation. Emphasize choosing a job first, then choosing an education.
